definitions: make a serious or urgent request to someone for help or support
be attractive or interesting to someone and cause them to like something
apply to a higher court for reversal of a lower court's decision
examples: The charity appeals to donors for emergency relief funds
Parents appealed to the school board for better safety measures
This movie will appeal to both children and adults alike
The new restaurant appeals to customers who enjoy authentic cuisine
The defendant decided to appeal the guilty verdict immediately
They will appeal the case to the Supreme Court tomorrow

definitions: officially or legally prohibit something from being done or used
forbid someone from entering or participating in a place or activity
examples: The government banned smoking in all public buildings nationwide
Many countries have banned the use of certain pesticides
The troublemaker was banned from the stadium for five years
She was banned from the online forum for violating rules

definitions: be a part of a whole or be equivalent to something
give legal or constitutional form to an institution or establish something formally
examples: These five members constitute the entire board of directors
Such actions constitute a breach of our employment contract
The president constituted a special committee to investigate the matter
They will constitute a new governing body next month

definitions: ask for divine favor or protection for someone or something
give approval or support to something officially or formally
endow someone with a particular cherished thing or attribute
examples: The priest blessed the congregation at the end of service
May God bless you and keep you safe always
The board blessed the merger with their unanimous approval vote
Her parents finally blessed their decision to marry next year
Nature blessed this region with abundant natural resources and beauty
She was blessed with an incredible singing voice from birth

definitions: collide violently with an obstacle or another vehicle causing damage
fail suddenly and completely especially of computer or financial systems
enter or attend a party or event without being invited
examples: The car crashed into the tree during the heavy storm
Two planes nearly crashed on the busy airport runway yesterday
My computer crashed and I lost all my unsaved work
The stock market crashed causing widespread financial panic globally
They decided to crash the wedding reception for free food
My cousin crashed at my apartment for three nights unexpectedly

definitions: institute legal proceedings against a person or institution typically for redress
make a formal request or appeal for something to someone in authority
examples: The company sued its former employee for breach of contract
She threatened to sue the newspaper for publishing false information
The diplomat sued for peace after months of violent conflict
The prisoner sued for mercy from the harsh judge

definitions: be unlike or dissimilar in nature, form, or quality from something else
have a different opinion from someone else about something
examples: The twins differ greatly in personality despite their identical appearance
Modern smartphones differ from early models in countless ways
We differ on how to solve this complex environmental problem
The committee members differed about the best course of action

definitions: run away from a place or situation of danger
leave or escape from a place or situation quickly or suddenly
examples: The villagers fled their homes when the volcano began erupting
The thief fled the scene before police officers arrived
Many refugees fled the country during the civil war period
She fled the uncomfortable conversation by making an excuse

definitions: interrupt an action or speech briefly before continuing with it again
stop and think before saying or doing something especially when uncertain
examples: The speaker paused dramatically before revealing the shocking truth
Let's pause the movie while I make some popcorn
She paused at the door uncertain whether to knock
He paused before answering the difficult question about his past

definitions: apply pressure and friction to a surface using a repeated back-and-forth motion
cause pain or irritation to part of the body through friction
examples: She rubbed sunscreen on her arms before going outside
The nurse rubbed alcohol on the skin before the injection
These new shoes rub against my heels causing painful blisters
The rough fabric rubbed his neck raw after hours

definitions: make someone unable to think clearly or understand something properly
mistake one person or thing for another due to similarity
examples: The complicated instructions confused everyone trying to assemble the furniture
Don't confuse the issue with irrelevant details and arguments
People often confuse me with my twin sister at parties
Students frequently confuse these two similar scientific terms

definitions: describe the distinctive nature or features of someone or something
be typical or characteristic of a particular person, place, or thing
examples: The report characterizes the situation as extremely urgent and dangerous
Critics characterize his writing style as both elegant and accessible
Patience and kindness characterize her approach to teaching young children
Heavy rainfall characterizes the climate of this tropical region

definitions: make something smaller or less in size, amount, intensity, or degree
become smaller or less in size, amount, intensity, or degree
examples: The company decreased production to match lower consumer demand levels
Exercise can decrease your risk of developing heart disease significantly
Sales decreased by twenty percent during the economic recession period
The pain should decrease gradually over the next few days

definitions: give particular emphasis or importance to a point or statement
subject to pressure or tension that causes mental or emotional strain
pronounce a word or syllable with greater emphasis than others
examples: The teacher stressed the importance of completing homework on time
I cannot stress enough how crucial this decision is
The deadline is really stressing me out this week
Financial problems have stressed their marriage for years now
In English you stress the first syllable of 'happiness'
Remember to stress the correct syllables when speaking formally

definitions: decide or announce that a planned event or arrangement will not take place
neutralize or negate the force or effect of something
examples: They had to cancel the outdoor concert due to severe weather
Please cancel my appointment with the dentist tomorrow morning
The positive and negative charges cancel each other out completely
These two opposing forces essentially cancel out any net effect

definitions: obtain something from a specified source through extraction or reasoning
arise from or originate in a particular source historically or logically
examples: Scientists derive this medicine from a rare tropical plant species
We can derive important conclusions from analyzing this data carefully
The word 'democracy' derives from ancient Greek language roots
His artistic style derives from early twentieth century modernist movements

definitions: maintain something at a certain rate or level over a period of time
suffer or experience something unpleasant especially an injury or loss
uphold, affirm, or confirm the justice or validity of something
examples: The athlete couldn't sustain her early pace throughout the marathon
This ecosystem cannot sustain such a large population indefinitely
The building sustained significant damage during the earthquake last night
He sustained a serious knee injury playing football yesterday
The judge sustained the prosecutor's objection to that line of questioning
The appeals court sustained the original verdict after careful review

definitions: make someone or something tranquil and quiet after stress or excitement
become tranquil and quiet after a period of stress or excitement
examples: The mother sang softly to calm her crying baby
Deep breathing exercises help calm anxiety before important presentations
The storm finally calmed after three hours of intense wind
Wait for him to calm down before discussing the problem

definitions: meet the expectations, needs, or desires of someone to make them content
provide someone with adequate information or proof to convince them
examples: This hearty meal will satisfy even the hungriest appetite
The company works hard to satisfy all customer complaints promptly
The evidence presented satisfied the jury of his complete innocence
Her explanation didn't satisfy my curiosity about the strange incident

definitions: remove or take away money from a bank account or place
remove oneself from participation in an activity or from a place
examples: She withdrew five hundred dollars from her savings account yesterday
The general ordered his troops to withdraw from enemy territory
He decided to withdraw from the competition due to injury
The company withdrew their controversial advertisement after public criticism

definitions: assign a job or role to someone officially through formal selection
arrange or decide on a time or place for something to happen
examples: The board appointed her as the new chief executive officer
The president will appoint three new judges this year
We appointed two o'clock as our meeting time tomorrow
They appointed the town hall as the venue for discussions

definitions: be convenient for or acceptable to someone's needs or preferences
enhance the appearance, features, or character of someone
examples: Would Monday morning suit you for our important meeting
This job would suit someone with strong communication skills perfectly
That blue dress really suits your complexion and style beautifully
Short hair suits her face shape much better than long

definitions: firmly press something soft or yielding typically with one's fingers
extract liquid or soft substance from something by compressing it firmly
manage to get into or through a narrow or restricted space
examples: She squeezed his hand reassuringly during the scary movie scene
Don't squeeze the bread loaf or it will become flat
Squeeze the orange to get fresh juice for breakfast
He squeezed every last drop of toothpaste from the tube
Can you squeeze through this narrow gap between the cars
We squeezed six people into the small elevator somehow

definitions: gradually grow faint and disappear or lose brightness of color
gradually grow faint and disappear from sight, memory, or prominence
examples: The curtains have faded from years of direct sunlight exposure
Dark clothes tend to fade after many washes
Her memories of childhood gradually faded over the years
The music slowly faded as we drove away from town

definitions: record something in written, photographic, or other permanent form for reference
support or accompany with documentation or written evidence
examples: The historian carefully documented every detail of the ancient civilization
Nurses must document all patient interactions in medical records
You need to document your expenses with receipts for reimbursement
The lawyer documented her claims with extensive email evidence

definitions: break or cause to break without complete separation of parts
solve or decipher something difficult like a code or problem
make or cause to make a sudden sharp or explosive sound
examples: The windshield cracked when a stone hit it yesterday
Don't crack the eggs until you're ready to cook
The detective finally cracked the mysterious case after months
Scientists are trying to crack the genetic code of aging
She cracked her knuckles nervously before the piano performance
The whip cracked loudly in the circus performer's hand

definitions: give out a bright light or be bright with reflected light
excel at something or perform at a very high level
make something bright by rubbing or polishing it
examples: The sun shines brightly through my bedroom window every morning
Her eyes shined with joy when she saw the surprise
She really shines when performing classical piano pieces on stage
This is your chance to shine in the competition
He shined his shoes until they looked brand new
The butler shined the silver before the dinner party

definitions: act dishonestly or unfairly to gain an advantage in something
be sexually unfaithful to one's partner in a relationship
examples: Several students were caught cheating on the final examination yesterday
He cheats at cards by marking them with invisible ink
She discovered her husband had been cheating for two years
If you cheat on your partner, trust is destroyed forever

definitions: tear or pull something quickly or forcibly away from something else
move forcefully or rapidly through a place or situation
examples: Be careful not to rip the delicate fabric while sewing
The strong wind ripped the poster off the wall completely
The speedboat ripped through the calm water at incredible speed
The guitarist ripped through an amazing solo during the concert

definitions: arrange systematically in a particular order based on importance or quality
have a specified position in a scale of achievement or status
examples: The teacher ranked the essays from best to worst quality
Search engines rank websites based on relevance and authority measures
She ranks among the top scientists in her specialized field
This university ranks third nationally for engineering programs

definitions: control or maintain something by means of rules and regulations
adjust the operation of a machine or process to accurate standards
examples: The government regulates pharmaceutical companies to ensure drug safety
New laws will regulate carbon emissions from factories next year
This thermostat regulates the temperature automatically throughout the day
The body regulates blood sugar levels through insulin production

definitions: make or become stronger or more powerful in physical or abstract terms
make something more intense, effective, or pronounced in its impact
examples: Regular exercise will strengthen your muscles and improve endurance
We need to strengthen security measures at the entrance
Their friendship strengthened through shared experiences over many years
The storm is expected to strengthen before reaching the coast

definitions: give someone a legal right or just claim to receive or do something
give a particular title or name to a book, composition, or work
examples: Your membership entitles you to use all gym facilities freely
This coupon entitles the bearer to one free coffee drink
She entitled her autobiography 'Journey Through the Storm'
The artist entitled the painting 'Sunset Over the Mountains'

definitions: investigate systematically into a subject to discover facts or information
engage in research work as a professional activity or occupation
examples: Scientists research the effects of climate change on ocean ecosystems
She spent months researching her family history in archives
He researches cancer treatments at the university medical center
Many students research part-time while completing their doctoral degrees

definitions: feel or cause to feel in need of rest or sleep from exertion
become bored with something or lose interest in it gradually
examples: The long hike really tired the children out completely
Working double shifts every day tires me mentally and physically
I quickly tire of eating the same lunch every single day
She never tires of listening to her favorite classical music

definitions: find or discover by investigation or searching carefully and systematically
copy a drawing or design by drawing over it on translucent paper
detect or find a very small amount of a substance
examples: Police traced the stolen car to an abandoned warehouse downtown
Historians trace our family lineage back to the sixteenth century
Children love to trace cartoon characters using tracing paper
She carefully traced the map outline for her geography project
Scientists traced amounts of pesticides in the water supply
The lab can trace even minute quantities of the chemical

definitions: burst or shatter violently and noisily as a result of internal pressure
increase suddenly or rapidly in size, number, or extent dramatically
suddenly express strong feelings especially of anger in a violent way
examples: The bomb exploded destroying several buildings in the area
Fireworks exploded colorfully in the night sky during celebrations
The city's population exploded during the technology boom years
Social media use has exploded among teenagers recently
He exploded with anger when he discovered the betrayal
She exploded at her assistant for the careless mistake

definitions: make something less warm or reduce its temperature significantly
become less hot gradually through exposure to air or time
remain calm and controlled despite provocation or difficult circumstances
examples: Cool the soup before putting it in the refrigerator
The air conditioning cools the entire building during summer
Let the engine cool down before checking the oil level
The weather should cool significantly by evening time
She managed to stay cool during the intense job interview
Try to keep cool when dealing with difficult customers

definitions: go beyond what is allowed or stipulated by a set limit
be greater in number or size than something else
examples: Drivers who exceed the speed limit risk getting expensive tickets
Don't exceed the recommended dosage on the medicine bottle
Sales this quarter exceed our most optimistic projections significantly
The final cost exceeded our budget by thirty percent

definitions: provide or give a service, help, or information to someone
cause someone or something to be in a particular state or condition
represent or depict artistically or translate into another language
examples: The hospital renders free medical services to low-income families
We are happy to render assistance during this difficult time
The accident rendered him unable to walk without assistance permanently
The storm rendered thousands of people homeless overnight
The artist rendered the landscape beautifully in watercolor paintings
Can you render this technical document into plain English

definitions: visit stores to buy goods or look at items for purchase
inform against someone to the authorities or betray them
examples: We shop for groceries every Saturday morning at the market
She loves to shop for vintage clothes at thrift stores
His former partner shopped him to the police for revenge
Never shop your colleagues to management over minor issues

definitions: give someone a sum of money as a reward for service
cause to lean or incline to one side or overturn
give someone information that is secret or not generally known
examples: Always tip your server at least fifteen percent for good service
He tipped the delivery driver generously during the holiday season
Be careful not to tip the canoe when getting in
The earthquake tipped several buildings off their foundations completely
Someone tipped off the police about the planned robbery tonight
She tipped me that the company plans major layoffs

definitions: rest or move on or near the surface of a liquid without sinking
move slowly or hover in a casual or aimless way
put forward an idea as a suggestion or test of reactions
examples: Dead leaves float on the surface of the pond
The rubber duck floats perfectly in the bathtub water
Clouds float lazily across the bright blue summer sky
The butterfly floated from flower to flower gathering nectar
Let me float this proposal to the board next week
She floated the idea of working from home permanently

definitions: create or design something that has not existed before through imagination
make up a story or excuse that is not true
examples: Thomas Edison invented the practical electric light bulb in 1879
Scientists are trying to invent new methods to combat pollution
He invented an elaborate excuse for missing the important meeting
Children often invent imaginary friends during early childhood years

definitions: revise, correct, or improve written material for accuracy and clarity
prepare written material for publication by correcting and modifying it
examples: Please edit your essay for grammar mistakes before submission
She spent hours editing the report to perfect every detail
He edits manuscripts for a major publishing house in London
The team will edit the documentary footage into a cohesive film

definitions: cause or bring about an action or feeling in someone
assist someone by suggesting the next words or action
done without delay or immediately when required
examples: The accident prompted new safety regulations at the factory
Her question prompted me to reconsider my original position completely
The teacher prompted the nervous student during the presentation
The director prompted the actor who forgot his lines
Please ensure prompt payment of all outstanding invoices
We guarantee prompt delivery within twenty-four hours

definitions: work or operate in a proper or particular way as intended
fulfill the purpose or task of a specified thing effectively
examples: The old computer still functions despite its age and appearance
His liver doesn't function properly due to years of alcohol abuse
This room functions as both office and guest bedroom
She functions as team leader when the manager is absent

definitions: state a fact or belief confidently and forcefully without proof
insist on having one's rights or position recognized by others
examples: The defendant continues to assert his innocence despite overwhelming evidence
Scientists assert that climate change poses serious threats to humanity
She learned to assert herself in business meetings effectively
Workers must assert their right to safe working conditions

definitions: deposit or discard garbage, waste, or unwanted material carelessly
end a romantic relationship with someone suddenly and unkindly
examples: Someone illegally dumped old furniture by the roadside last night
The factory was caught dumping toxic waste into the river
He dumped his girlfriend via text message on Valentine's Day
She dumped him after discovering his lies about everything

definitions: carry out or put into effect a plan, order, or action
carry out a sentence of death on a legally condemned person
examples: The team executed the project plan flawlessly within budget constraints
The computer executes thousands of instructions per second efficiently
The state executed the convicted murderer at midnight yesterday
Several conspirators were executed for plotting against the king
